Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Sustainable Futures Protocol: A New Social Science Research Vehicle to Identify and Develop Key Psychological and Sociocultural Competencies for Sustainability Worldwide
Award.AbstractNarration:
A growing number of researchers are taking-up the many social and cultural challenges of transitioning toward global sustainability. While rapid global warming and extreme weather are often at the forefront of these challenges there are many more, including reduction in poverty; managing migration; improving access to water, healthcare, and education worldwide; sustainable development of limited natural resources, etc. These challenges, although global, are particularly acute in the Arctic, which is socially and culturally quite diverse. In order to cross culturally negotiate these diverse sets of sustainability challenges, interdisciplinary teams of researchers must work together, as well as with local and non-local scholars and experts and variety of stakeholders and community members. It is in this complex landscape of sustainability challenges, scholarship, socio-economic and cultural systems, and political geography that this project has the potential to inform future research methods and global solutions.

This research project seeks to help develop interdisciplinary researcher, local scholar, stakeholder, and community member teams so that they can best work together within and across cultures and within and across challenges. In addition the project will support these leadership teams as their network grows globally through web-based platforms. The main goal of the project is to identify the key social and psychological characteristics, individually and collectively, that lead to community leaders that understand and are willing to invest in sustainability ideas and projects. Support is given to the PI to develop and test a complex of social science research methods and tools, labeled the Sustainable Futures Protocols, by which the most optimal competencies for collaboration and coordination of actions for sustainability can be understood, measured, and, perhaps most importantly, achieved. The cross cultural component of the research project will be the development and testing of the Sustainable Futures Protocol in Arctic, Caribbean, and USA communities. Results from this work will provide a testing, teaching, and development tool for individuals and groups with regard to community leadership and optimal community dynamics for sustainability. It will provide a guideline of skills that can be developed individually or at the community level in order facilitate decisions about a global sustainable future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many schools recognize that students of all ages need to learn important new skills for life and work in the 21st-century. Among these, key skills for collaboration, teamwork, and knowledge translation across differences of context, culture, and expertise have been identified. These include a set of interpersonal and intrapersonal competencies that have psychological and sociocultural dimensions. Unlike reading, writing, and arithmetic, however, there are currently no unitary shared mechanisms in education for teaching or testing these skills. This project set-out to begin to solve this problem.

In this project, a new toolkit for education that leads to the development of skills for life and work in the 21st-century was created and initially tested. Called the Transdisciplinary Research Education Toolkit, its initial design integrates the large body of research that exists on teaching and learning through community engagement with the most recent advances being taken in transdisciplinary research on social and environmental problems.

Community engagement for students is often utilized by schools to integrate formal in-class education with informal real-world teaching and learning, but usually without the benefits of including transdisciplinary research methods. Transdisciplinary research is an approach that expands on interdisciplinary research by connecting academics and students with communities to find collaborative solutions to social and environmental problems. Community participants in transdisciplinary research can include a variety of individuals and groups with wide-ranging expertise and vested community interests. It is often conducted through small group projects that may include a few students. What the Transdisciplinary Research Education Toolkit does is make these projects bigger and more effective, so that more students can participate and learn. Importantly, it focuses that learning particularly, but not exclusively, on the development and testing of interpersonal and intrapersonal psychological and sociocultural skills needed for collaboration, teamwork, and knowledge translation.

The Transdisciplinary Research Education Toolkit has three main components that were created and initially tested in this project. These are, a) the Sustainable Futures Protocol (SFP), which is an initial curriculum that serves as a transdisciplinary research teaching and learning tool, b) an assessment and monitoring tool called the Global Sustainability Inventory (GSI), and, c) an international cross-cultural network research collaboration tool called the Global Social Sustainability Hub (GSSH). In terms of their broader contribution to the sciences, an objective with the SFP is to help forward research on the optimization of collaborative learning, including that in the fields of team science, leadership development, knowledge management, and transdisciplinary research. The scientific purpose of the GSI is to serve as a full spectrum assessment tool that will characterize the various impacts of the Transdisciplinary Research Education Toolkit, and provide data through individual and community status reports before, during, and after projects. The scientific purpose of the GSSH is to serve as a transdisciplinary research integration platform for the development of international cross-cultural collaborative networks that help to organize, strategize, and mobilize action that engages social and environmental problems. The overall research data and outcomes provided by the Transdisciplinary Research Education Toolkit, then, will be of wide interest and value to teachers and researchers across academic disciplines as well as policy makers in government.

This project was awarded an EAGER type grant from NSF. EAGER refers to an EArly Grant for Exploratory Research. Early, exploratory, development of the toolkit was initiated through collaborative research with remote communities in the Arctic as well as highly populated urban centers internationally. Funded through the Arctic Social Sciences Program at NSF, development of the toolkit was accelerated forward through consistent efforts by its Program Director to connect this project with other social science research activities worldwide. While the project was based out of George Mason University, collaborative research and peer review included, among others, colleagues at Howard University, Old Dominion University, MIT and Columbia University. Inputs to design and testing were generated from collaborative work with various cultures including the Inuit of Nunavut and Nunatsiavut, the Maya of Guatemala, and the small island Caribbean cultures in the West Indies. This degree of participation in various collaborative activities worldwide during the five-year tenure of this project helped evolve it from its initial focus on the Sustainable Futures Protocol to the much more comprehensive Transdisciplinary Research Education Toolkit.

As shown in the attached illustration, the Transdisciplinary Research Education Toolkit utilizes the various tools at both the individual participant and communities (collective) levels to inform and guide the research-based development and dissemination of 21st-century interpersonal and intrapersonal skills.

Future research with the Transdisciplinary Research Education Toolkit will test its efficacy and validity as the basis of a unitary shared mechanism in education for teaching and testing key interpersonal and intrapersonal skills for collaboration, teamwork, and knowledge translation across differences of context, culture, and expertise. For research purposes, as shown in the infographic, this larger mechanism has been called the Core Curriculum for Civic Engagement (CC4CE).
